Award.AwardTitle: Midwest Regional Robert Noyce Connections 2014-2015: Building Communities of Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The primary goal of the conference - Midwest Regional Robert Noyce Connections 2014-2015: Building Communities of Practice is to continue to strengthen a network of peer support for Noyce Teacher Scholarship project personnel and Noyce Scholars. This will improve Noyce program effectiveness throughout the 15 states of the Midwest region. The project goal will be accomplished through facilitating an annual conference in 2014 and 2015 and a suite of year-round networking opportunities for conference participants that are designed to accomplish four objectives: 1) increase the personal connections among Midwest Noyce project members; 2) utilize these new and/or strengthened connections to share expertise and knowledge across Midwest Noyce projects; 3) support the professional development of Noyce Scholars; and 4) build a community of practice among Noyce scholars. The two conferences - which will be held in Omaha, Nebraska October 2-3, 2014 and October 1-2, 2015 - will continue a 2009 to 2012 tradition of bringing together 250 Noyce investigators, pre-service and in-service Noyce Scholars, school district personnel, and project evaluation and assessment experts from the 62 active Noyce projects in Arkansas, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Wisconsin so that they may benefit from each others? experiences. Year-round networking and learning activities (e.g., online community, webinars, and workshops) will provide additional opportunities for Noyce personnel and Noyce Scholars to continuously learn from each other. As evidenced by the title, the theme that will unite this two-year project is Building Communities of Practice.

Intellectual Merit:

Midwest Regional Robert Noyce Connections 2014-2016: Grounding STEM Learning for All is a collaborative project with PIs at the University of Nebraska, Illinois State University, Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis, and Wittenberg University. The primary goal of Midwest Regional Robert Noyce Connections 2014-2016: Grounding STEM Learning for All is to continue to strengthen a network of peer support for Noyce Teacher Scholarship project personnel and Scholars across the Midwest, thereby improving Noyce program effectiveness throughout the region. In order to accomplish this goal, we pursued the following four objectives:

Objective 1:     Increase the personal connections among Midwest Noyce project members;

Objective 2:     Utilize these new and/or strengthened connections to share expertise and knowledge across Midwest Noyce projects;

Objective 3:     Support the professional development of Noyce Scholars; and

Objective 4:    Build a community of practice among Noyce Scholars.

The 15-state Midwest region is defined for this project as Arkansas, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Dakota and Wisconsin.

Broader Impacts:

Each year, 2014-2016, Noyce Connections held a major conference. Prior to the first two conferences, we worked with our evaluator to conduct a needs assessment among Midwest Noyce personnel, to better craft the conferences to meet the needs of our target audience. Throughout the conferences, a focus on equity/diversity was a common thread, to help Noyce teachers better engage all students in math/science teaching and learning. In 2014 and 2015, the conferences were in October of the year, and held in Omaha, Nebraska. In 2016, the conference was held in June in Titusville, Florida, at the Kennedy Space Center. The two Omaha conferences featured nationally-known plenary speakers, a “voices from the field” panel, concurrent breakout sessions by Noyce PIs, evaluators, and Scholars, a poster session, and other networking opportunities. A highlight in 2014 was the panel on cultural competency, featuring Noyce Scholars from Eastern Michigan University, most of whom were currently student teaching. The panel was able to talk from personal experience about power, identity, stereotype threat, and teaching with cultural competency. A highlight in 2015 was the plenary presentation by Dr. Roni Ellington, Regaining STEAM in STEM Education through Transcending Boundaries: A Transformative Framework for Educating ALL Students. Dr. Ellington is a dynamic and engaging speaker who was able to connect with the audience around issues related to effective teaching in high-need schools through building relationships with students. A highlight in 2016 was the plenary presentation and Q&A time with astronaut Sam Durrance.

Along with the major conferences, Noyce Connections planned to host local conferences (“drive-in workshops”) and webinars. These included:

  • Local Workshop, Flip The Project for Math and Science, Edwardsville, Illinois, February 28, 2015 and Indianapolis, Indiana, March 28, 2015
  • Local Workshop, Improve Diverse Students’ Engagement in STEM Learning By Design, Indianapolis, Indiana, March 14, 2015
  • Local Workshop, Dine, Dialogue and Pass it On, Lincoln, Nebraska, April 25, 2015
  • Webinars in 2015: a two-part series focused on Using the Wheel without Reinventing It: What to Examine for Noyce Project Evaluation. The webinars were led by our evaluation team at RMC Research; recordings are archived on our website.
  • Local Workshop, Project Based Learning, Indianapolis, Indiana, April 15, 2016 and November 4-5, 2016

In 2014, we launched a LinkedIn group, Midwest Regional Noyce Community. Many Noyce project personnel joined this group, and we launched several discussion questions for the group to consider prior to the 2015 conference.

As part of the 2016 conference, we asked Noyce Scholars to create lesson plans related to what they learned about integrated STEM lessons; those lesson plans are online in a shared folder for all the participants.
